item.title: Why It's Impossible to Get Your Car Repaired This Summer
item.description: A shortage of parts and technicians, more complex auto technology, and older cars on the road are creating a perfect storm; Ford and GM are concerned.

item.title: Where Is Abortion Legal in the U.S.? A State-by-State Guide to Abortion Access
item.description: Abortion access in the U.S. has changed considerably since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade. Track where abortion is now legal, banned or under threat.

item.title: Why It's Impossible to Get Your Car Repaired This Summer
item.description: A shortage of parts and technicians, more complex auto technology, and older cars on the road are creating a perfect storm; Ford and GM are concerned

item.title: Brazil's electoral court barred Bolsonaro from seeking office until 2030, finding he undermined confidence in the nation's voting system before losing last year's presidential election.
item.description: Brazil’s electoral court barred Bolsonaro from seeking office until 2030, finding he undermined confidence in the nation’s voting system before losing last year’s presidential election.

item.title: Goldman is in talks with American Express to take over its Apple credit card and other ventures with the tech giant, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.description: Goldman is in talks with American Express to take over its Apple credit card and other ventures with the tech giant, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: ESPN cut about 20 on-screen commentators, including longtime basketball anchor Jeff Van Gundy.
item.description: ESPN cut about 20 on-screen commentators, including longtime basketball anchor Jeff Van Gundy.

item.title: The CIA's Burns reached out to his Russian counterpart in the wake of a failed mutiny by Wagner's chief, delivering a message that the U.S. had no involvement in Russia's internal chaos, officials familiar with the matter said.
item.description: The CIA’s Burns reached out to his Russian counterpart in the wake of a failed mutiny by Wagner’s chief, delivering a message that the U.S. had no involvement in Russia’s internal chaos, officials familiar with the matter said.

item.title: The SEC said a recent wave of applications filed by asset managers to launch spot bitcoin ETFs are inadequate, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.description: The SEC said a recent wave of applications filed by asset managers to launch spot bitcoin ETFs are inadequate, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: U.S. stocks rose Friday, with the Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow gaining 1.4%, 1.2% and 0.8%, respectively.
item.description: U.S. stocks rose Friday, with the Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow gaining 1.4%, 1.2% and 0.8%, respectively.

item.title: Consumer prices and spending rose more slowly in May, but the Fed likely remains on track to raise interest rates in July amid recent signs of healthy economic activity.
item.description: Consumer prices and spending rose more slowly in May, but the Fed likely remains on track to raise interest rates in July amid recent signs of healthy economic activity.

item.title: Apple became the world's first corporation to close with a market value exceeding $3 trillion.
item.description: Apple became the world’s first corporation to close with a market value exceeding $3 trillion.

item.title: The high court sided with a Colorado web designer's claim that the First Amendment entitles her to refuse commissions for same-sex wedding announcements.
item.description: The high court sided with a Colorado web designer’s claim that the First Amendment entitles her to refuse commissions for same-sex wedding announcements.

item.title: Any number of things could have derailed markets in the first half of the year, but investors kept buying risky assets anyway. Stocks burst out of a bear market, bitcoin surged and bonds enjoyed some reprieve, too.
item.description: Any number of things could have derailed markets in the first half of the year, but investors kept buying risky assets anyway. Stocks burst out of a bear market, bitcoin surged and bonds enjoyed some reprieve, too.

item.title: The Supreme Court threw out the Biden administration's plan to forgive student loans held by 40 million Americans, ending a $430 billion program the White House considers a crucial way to cement the president's support among younger Americans.
item.description: The Supreme Court threw out the Biden administration’s plan to forgive student loans held by 40 million Americans, ending a $430 billion program the White House considers a crucial way to cement the president’s support among younger Americans.

item.title: A report on the State Department's chaotic 2021 exit from Afghanistan said senior Biden administration officials were to blame for failing to decide which Afghans should be eligible for evacuation and issuing constantly changing guidance.
item.description: A report on the State Department’s chaotic 2021 exit from Afghanistan said senior Biden administration officials were to blame for failing to decide which Afghans should be eligible for evacuation and issuing constantly changing guidance.

item.title: Where Affirmative Action Succeeded---and Where It Fell Short
item.description: Affirmative action helped more nonwhites get on campus and in the office, but societal wealth gaps have proved persistent.

item.title: Ukraine's Deadly New Missile Was Created to Hit Saddam Hussein in His Bathtub
item.description: Storm Shadow, an ultraprecise British cruise missile, is letting Kyiv hit Russian targets at much greater distance.

item.title: Amid San Francisco's Woes, Elon Musk Plays Critic
item.description: Since becoming one of San Francisco’s highest-profile employers, Twitter’s owner has had much to say about the state of affairs in the city, describing it in a tweet as feeling ‘post-apocalyptic.’
